div.head: Bibliography

div.p: Titus Pompeius Ligyrus, from Autricum, aged 40, cavalryman of the the cohort of Spaniards, having served 20 years, lies here; Clemens, for his patron.

div.head: Commentary
div.p: On this text see W. Wagner Die Dislocation das römischen Auxiliarformationen in den Provinzen Noricum, Pannonien, Moesiem und Dakien; The text was dated by Ghislanzoni in the second century CE. But the letter forms and formulae (eque ex cohorte, aera = stipendium, hic situs) suggest rather the first half of the first century CE. This assessment is of course is highly subjective, and it must be admitted that in Cyrenaica where most inscriptions are in Greek the number of dated Latin texts for comparison is small. But if this dating is correct we must reject the suggestion of Romanelli, Cirenaica 192f., followed by Applebaum, JJS II (1950)30, that the cohort (perhaps II Hispanorum Scutata Cyrenaica, see Romanelli, loc.cit. and CIL XVI, 110 of 159 A.D). had been temporarily moved from its normal station on the Danube during the Jewish Revolt of 115 CE The absence of the dedication dis manibus, in any of its forms and the use of the nominative case for the subject are again suggestive of the first century rather than a later date. The inscription must belong to an earlier phase in the history of the cohort, before it went to the Danube region.
Line 7: The cohort also appears in C.726, lines 4-5, q.v. for a discussion of its identity; see also P.220.
Line 8: This form seems to have been particularly popular in Spain, see Ritterling, loc.cit.

There are some indications to suggest that the men concerned were actually Spaniards, and if so, it is probable, although of course not certain that they were in service comparatively soon after the unit was recruited, or at least, after it left Spain. Thus Pompeius Ligyrus is perhaps better regarded as a man of the Cantabrian tribe of Autricones (Autrigones) than as supposed at first a man from Autricum; both he and Sempronius Macer (C.726) bear nomina which are relatively common in Spain as a result of the Gracchan and Pompeian connections with the peninsula (Aemilius is common enough there too, but not particularly characteristic). As against all this it must be said that it is unexpected to find three full Roman citizens serving as auxiliaries in the first century (four if the brother Aemilius Macer is assumed to be fellow soldier), two of them sons of Roman citizens. It is also rare for auxiliary men to mention ranks in the first century but not unknown. Neither can be regarded as absolute bars to a first century date. If a first century date were accepted it would be reasonable hypothesis, I think, that the unit was brought to Cyrenaica in the course of the Marmaric War of the Augustan period and remainded in garrison there for a time thereafter. An armed garrison at Cyrene itself and in Ptolemais is fully understandable in this context; detachments may well have been placedfor a time in all the cities of the province. subsequently units may have been sent away and those that remained seem to have been withdrawn to the limes forts.
